title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
U.S. stocks extended their April losses, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow sinking 2.8%, 4% and 2.4%, respectively. All three indexes are on track to lose at least 4% this month.

---

A top EU regulator cautioned Musk a day after he struck a deal to buy Twitter that he would need to follow the bloc's new rules on content moderation.

Tesla shares logged their biggest one-day drop in more than a year, retreating 12% to $876.42.

---

Mattel has held talks with private-equity firms about a potential sale, people familiar with the matter said.

---

Fed governor Brainard won confirmation in a 52-43 vote by the Senate to become the central bank's vice chairwoman.

---

Microsoft's revenue and profit rose in the latest quarter as demand for its cloud services and software continued to climb.

---

Google parent Alphabet posted slower sales growth as global economic turmoil disrupted digital advertising spending.

---

Warner Bros. Discovery's Zaslav said the company wouldn't spend wildly to boost its various news and entertainment assets when it comes to streaming.

---

GM's profit slipped 3% in the first quarter. The auto maker stood by its 2022 earnings forecast.

---

GE warned that its business would be pressured by supply-chain disruptions this year.
